The twilight of Morocco's King Mohammed VI
subhead: 'The Enigma of Mohammed VI' (1/6). Twenty-six years after his 1999 coronation, the Moroccan monarch's relationship to power remains complex. As questions about his health arise, the prospect of his succession is fueling power struggles and backroom deals among the country's elite.

subhead: The Palestinian city, located on the border with Egypt and whose development dates back to the Pharaohs, is now a field of rubble, writes historian Jean-Pierre Filiu in his column.

title: Labubu craze leads to shortages and surge in counterfeits
subhead: Pop Mart, the Beijing-based company behind the collectible figurines, reports record half-year results but struggles to meet demand despite automating its factories.

title: Irish rap band Kneecap chant 'Free Palestine' at Paris concert despite criticism
subhead: They were performing on Sunday at Rock en Seine festival. Liam O'Hanna, who performs under the stage name Mo Chara, was charged in England in May accused of displaying a flag of the Lebanese militant group Hezbollah during a London concert in November.

title: François Truffaut's obsession with Isabelle Adjani
subhead: 'Adjani, The Famous Stranger' (2/6). While making a name for herself at the Comédie Française, the young actress became the French filmmaker's obsession, who courted her insistently on the set of 'The Story of Adèle H.' in 1975. She resisted him and made her mark with a performance full of restrained violence.

Is 'abundance' the new watchword of US Democrats?
subhead: Born in California, the concept of 'abundance' has captivated the centrist wing of the Democratic Party. It advocates for an interventionist state paired with deregulation to facilitate investment and increase the supply of essential goods such as housing, energy, transportation and healthcare.

title: Spike in suspicious incidents in Iran fuels fears of a simmering war
subhead: Iranians remain on edge two months after the end of the 12-day war, worried about renewed fighting with Israel and burdened by inflation and water and power shortages.

title: Being a writer in the digital age? James Baldwin 'seemed free in ways we no longer can be'
subhead: 'Letters from America' (6/6). Writer and journalist Thomas Chatterton Williams envies the great American author's bohemian, technology-free existence, despite the chaos it represented.
